cons: - Only one I found was limited opportunity to advance in my field.  Only so many positions to move up to and most are filled people that don't appear to be leaving anytime soon.

review_title: Great place to work if you like being bought and are motivated by fear.
pros: It's a growing university at a time when most are struggling. Attractive campus. Compensation and benefits are pretty good, especially for a starting position. It's a great place to be if you like work, stress, and being bought. Great place to be if you're a ultra-conservative Republican. The administration is very ideologically biased toward tea party Republicans and fundamentalist Christians.
cons:
The rapid growth is handled poorly - people are maxed out and things change so quickly that no one knows what the rules are. Policies change overnight. You are held accountable regardless.

The administration do not have a category for a good faculty person or good teacher. They seem to base their opinions of faculty on today's myths of the bad tenured faculty who don't do much and don't care about students. So they take as much power away from faculty, rank has no impact on compensation, tenure does not exist, they design courses in a generic way so anyone, without any qualifications in the field, could teach a class, and then overload the faculty with meaningless busy work. Moreover, administration are all from online universities or have their degrees from Grand Canyon University (!), so their only paradigm is online instructors which are more facilitators and graders of student-based learning. In fact, there is a very suspicious attitude toward traditional faculty, and if students are doing poorly, they treat it like the faculty is the problem; we are hounded by multiple staffers (reminds me of the Office Space and how everyone badgers about the TPS reports) about what we are doing to get the student back on track.

The work environment is hostile and fear-based, consisting of extreme micromanagement and little employee empowerment. The people who last are "Yes-men;" making a decision for yourself or voicing an opinion contrary to upper management's is the surest way to be terminated. Faculty are constantly told not to put concerns in writing because it could be used against us. Of course, there is no faculty senate or representation to the administration. Faculty therefore have no input and no way to advocate for better circumstances to improve their job performance. We are told to watch what we say in front of students. We can't advise students to do graduate work elsewhere, even if it's best for them. Upper management motivate by fear and money: they yell and threaten termination, bullying lower managers and staff into submission. Of course, when administration start to feel heat because of this contempt for employees, they give you a bonus and say "Thank you for all you do..." Money covers their multitude of sins. It is no wonder why Ken Blanchard had his name removed from the College of Business. 

Faculty have little control over the curriculum: assignments are dictated by online constraints - no quizzes or tests because of cheating, textbooks are governed by profit margins and business deals with publishers (forget using academic quality texts), lectures are not factored into class material, since they are not part of online platform. Most of what we use is wildly out of date or poor, and the assignments we create are really shallow, simplistic, and absurd. Most of the faculty only have masters degrees and so we can't create courses that are cutting edge, because most can't teach that material. We create inferior courses.

Everything is analytics based, and they will ride you if you are not meeting their predetermined but not communicated standards. Moreover, they have no capacity to value what can't be measured, like classroom preparation or meeting with students.

There is a system for everything. This means a task takes forever as you often have to work on three different interfaces or websites to complete a simple task. Moreover, these systems are poorly integrated. For example, LoudCloud - the Learning Management System - organizes students by first name. The faculty portal - a different system - where we enter midterm and final grades organizes students by last name. Also, here's an interesting insight into GCU culture: midterm grades are never shown to the students. Midterms are about assessing the faculty, not the students.

The turnover here is a great indicator of the kind of environment you're getting into: 18months. And the administration doesn't bat an eye. The bottom line is: you don't matter to them; if you leave, they'll just fill your spot with someone else, preferably someone unqualified so they'll have no choice but to take the bullying and stick around, since they would never get hired in the same position elsewhere.

By way of summary I would say you are micromanaged and disempowered, and you are forced to micromanage and disempower your students. This is destructive of both the work environment and the educational environment. You have a very antagonistic experience with students and colleagues don't want to spend time with each other to build a faculty culture because everyone just wants to get out as quickly as possible.

review_title: Exemplary service means nothing if you're not friends with power players.

Pay for enrollment is comparatively high but the "pain" you will go through in this place is not worth it.

review_title: Ridged micromanagement, lack of support, corporate machine-like environment
pros: Great health benefits! It’s one of the only area’s employees are given any choice over.  I have better health insurance that I have had in many years.
cons:
- Micromanagement to the Nth degree! 
- Completely inflexible work schedules!
- Totally unrealistic expectations! Set up for failure right from the start!
- Why bother to offer PTO if employees can never actually use it!?!
- The Employee Handbook reads like a pre-signed severance package.  Proceed with caution! The policies are always changing (for both employees and for students). Can't keep up with it.
- ZERO transparency! I don’t believe management has their employees or even the university students best interests in mind in their operational structure.  
- My department moved to a location off-campus a few months ago.  It’s a warehouse, no windows, full of cubes in lines. Feels like an assembly line or sweatshop. 
-Very, very process heavy!  They do not encourage any individuality or critical thinking at all.  There is no such thing as autonomy in any way shape or form.  Might as well be grade school with recess and bathroom breaks.

job_title: Enrollment Counselor Doctoral in Tempe, AZ
pros: "Free" tuition. You pay taxes on your tuition for masters and doctoral classes. It is not free. You will pay 10-33% directly from your paycheck.
cons:
Micromanagement is terrible. We get told not to leave our desks at certain times. Our manager keeps track of bathroom breaks inaccurately and then accuses us of taking longer breaks. 
Lately marketing has been failing big time and management refused to hear it for month and months. It took rumors of layoffs and people leaving for them to finally take a hint that it's not us, it's them. They said that they'd use "natural attrition" instead of layoffs. Basically they stopped buying leads and forced people to leave for poor performance.
  Most people don't finish this program so we are basically enrolling people with high debt already into the program. I've seen students with 180-250k in loans. GCU is taking advantage of them.
There is 0 chances for mobility in doctoral. Especially for the women. Making a lateral move out isn't even an option. You are stuck once you get there. 
Numbers have been impossible lately. Our goal is 4 but lately getting 2 is good. 
Also the salary sucks. This division is known for not giving the full 4% yearly raise. And don't expect the highest yearly raise of around 3% unless you are a man.

job_title: ENROLLMENT COUNSELOR/TEAM LEAD in Phoenix, AZ

cons: Terrible leads, pushy sales tactics. Employees are still expected to enroll a specific amount of students despite the changing industry and underwhelming tools.

review_title: I enjoyed everyday, it will probably be the best/most fun job I'll ever have.
job_title: Food Service Administrative Assistant in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Free food on the clock, networking in the department, learn a lot  of management skills, boss becomes your friend, salary increase with time.
cons: Sometimes and with all management jobs you have to be the "bad guy" this means if a friend works for the POS you manage you have to call them out when they are doing bad.

pros: The benefits aren’t even worth the headache or stress of the job. There’s no job security in this position whatsoever.
cons: Where do I begin? This company is an actual joke to work for, Brian Mueller is going to do exactly the same thing that he did for university of Phoenix where he expands at a tremendous rate and then plateaus, makes millions and leaves. Being a university counselor means sitting in a cubicle making cold calls all day and trying to get someone on the phone that supposedly inquired in 2007 who have been called about 200 times since then. The entire training process is not about learning the programs or learning about the university itself it’s about getting someone on the phone long enough to have a conversation with them and hoping that they’ll answer again to sell them on the school so that you can get your X amount of enrollments that you need per month, but we’re not a sales job were “counselors”. This is a numbers based job where if you over exceed by five enrollments one month but you missed the next two month by 1 enrollment you go on a corrective action plan (CAP) aka a write up. They throw write ups out like it’s candy which stops you from moving to a different position or doing anything else within the company. The corrective action plans are not based on behavior but they’re based on numbers but we’re not a sales job let me reiterate that we’re not a sales job. How can you expect Your employees to get any type of enrollments on a consistent basis with the leads that you give them and dealing with financial aid issues because everyone these days are in default or have other financial aid issues and can’t get them enrolled. How is that the university counselors fault? But you want to throw a write up to them because they had financial aid issues and couldn’t hit their number. If you’re going to work for Grand Canyon University or Grand Canyon education I would definitely recommend staying as far away from the University counselor position as possible. The turnover rate for this position is also something that they need to pay attention to as well because there has to be an issue when I was in a training class of 55 and there’s only about 13 of us left from 8 months ago and I’m leaving as well. there is a new training class of about 40 to 50 people per month and that’s because the turnover is so high. Buy better leads in your turnover rate would not be as high.

review_title: GCU is a growing for-profit higher education organization when other colleges are downsizing.
pros: The organization is growing due to the innovation of CEO and his ability to get things done.  Opportunity for advancement, great benefits including education, focus on academic quality, transparency throughout operations.
cons: Its a mystery how some executive leaders are in their positions since their actions hurt performance instead of help and they contribute to the loss of great talent.

review_title: Great place to work, not a lot of incentive

review_title: Cliquish, egotistical, backstabbing coworkers, dehumanizing bosses, cultish atmosphere, LOUSY pay, NO support.
pros: There's a paycheck every two weeks. It's CRAP given what breed of bacon wrapped , sophomoric, high-school caliber "I'll only talk to him/her if he/she is hot and/or bangable and has cash" BS we have to put up with, but that's about it.
cons: I've been working here for two years, and only stay here to keep the lights on in my house. As soon as something better opens up, I'm gone. Whoever said that this was a great place to work is either not all that smart, or possesses the kind of personality that Koresh or Manson would truly love . The managers routinely berate, condescend and insult new hires to the point of encouraging them to quit-I recently heard one of our managers on the West side of our enrollment center do this to someone who I later found out was a new hire-this they did while a group of (I assume were that manager's subordinate enrollment counselors) chuckled to themselves while listening to such statements as "you're just not cut out for this. Admit it, there's no shame in it. You're just not all that smart, and this job is for smart people!" That was three days ago, and I filed an HR grievance on that EC's behalf-HR has yet to get back to me about this. Goodness help you of you are a new hire and don't look like something out of GQ magazine or don't brag about driving a high end car, as you will be isolated by your coworkers as "not being 'on  par'...ya know, I've been here for as long as I have and still don't know what that means...as far as work, you will be expected to make at least 100 dials a day, have two to three hours of talk time (which, honestly, is a ton) AND register three to five students per month (with only one new incoming call per week on average, and 5000 time-waster leads from people who haven't spoken to an enrollment counselor in three years, again this is a tall order.) If you bring a tablet in for note taking purposes, expect to be labelled a "jack---" and laughed at. Expect to be fired if you use the internet. Expect to be disciplined if you use the company provided IM service for anything other than advising your boss that you are on break. This is NOT a good place to work. I would rather have worked at the IRS.

job_title: Junior Event Planner in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good benefits, flexible schedule, able to advance quickly if you work hard.
cons: The department I was in had a bit of a turnover rate. Our manager worked around 60+ hours a week doing a job that should have been done by 2 people. They did bring in another person, but there was a lot of shifting of roles, and confusion on who to report to.

pros: The pay is ok and the job itself doesn't suck. There are some good people that work here and it is kind of nice working on campus with so many students and activities going on.
cons:
I Was lied to from day one about the increase in my pay once I passed my one year, job expectations and about the ability to move up in the company.  It is extremely hard to even make a lateral move, much less move up. A lot of people in management treat employees like they are second class citizens, me included. They lead by fear and intimidation. 
One of my co-workers was hired and singed an offer letter for another position on campus. A few days later she was pulled into a meeting where our manager decided to block her from moving because they wanted her to stay where she as at. 
I had a similar experience, except I never was officially offered the position. The director of one of the departments outside of admissions wanted to hire me for a specific job but needed permission from my current supervisor to do it. Needless to say, they said no, and I was not even interviewed.
 They are also very aggressive about numbers. If you don't meet your numbers you are hounded. They give you a brand new territory and expect you to recruit at least 35 students, which is impossible. The highest number of students that attended gcu last year from my territory was 5. I can't take 5 and turn it into 35 in just a few months. When you don't meet your numbers, then they put you on cap, which is a disciplinary action plan. This is the reason I am turning in my two weeks tomorrow. If after 90 days you still can't meet your numbers, you end up getting fired.  Me and my coworker that have both been there over a year are on cap for not making numbers, even though our numbers are way better than last year's numbers. To top it all off, my coworker is also expecting. They have not provided her with any accommodations and now she has to find a new job with a baby on the way. It's just crazy. It's like no one cares. 
Also take note, they do not promote from within very often. They usually hire brand new graduates for the higher paying UAC positions. Overall, very poor experience. (there are so many other issues, but these are the worst ones.)

pros: GCU is a growing, thriving university that offers employees a good salary & benefits package and ample opportunity for advancement.
cons: Any company that experiences the rapid growth that we have seen will experience growing pains as processes and systems struggle at time to keep up...

review_title: High expectations, Low Pay, Inconsistent Work, Disrespectful Students
pros: I got paid every 2 weeks versus every month.  Didn't have to work during the holidays
cons:
The biggest reason why GCU is NOT a place to work is the pay.  Years back they decided to create a new system of paying per student, versus paying per class.  The worst part is that they haven't changed this system in over 10 years.  But, they continue to increase tuition. 

You are expected to be online 4-5 days a week, including one weekend.  BUT, you are expected to go online and answer questions on the private discussion board within 24 hours.  I asked one of the faculty leads how do I do that unless I'm expected to log in every day and that's not what the expectations are.  She wrote back, "You are expected to respond within 24 hours"  OK so every day then.  

3 weeks of non-paid training.  

You get these terrible automatic emails stating you didn't login enough or your grading is behind but no one ever reaches out to find out if there is something wrong with you, or are you having family issues. 

If you fall behind on their expectations, you will be fired, no questions asked, no ability to respond.  But, we are bend over backwards for students, give them extensions, re-grade papers, etc.  A Christian-based school that doesn't support their own Christian values for their staff. 

Students complain about everything, even if you give them your entire expectations up-front.  I provided a list of things to do and how to do it with examples, they don't read it, then get mad.  These are graduate students. 

You have no control over the class size so you can't adequately budget.  You may have a class of 1 student and that pays $500 and then have a class of 8 students that also pay $500.  Or you may have a class of 26 students that pays $2100.  That's about 90 dollars per student for 8 weeks of responding to discussion boards, grading papers every week and grading discussion board, posting announcements.  

To treat people this way is horrible.  

You charge students over $3k for  class and pay the instructor less than $100. Shame on you.  No wonder they can continue to expand on their campus, advertise, and offer these great things. 

You get no computer, no compensation for internet, they don't even have the ability use Microsoft Office by logging in.  They are as bad as UBER.

I feel bad for the students because they aren't getting really instructions.  I was a glorified grader. I sat and graded papers for hours and days on end.  Many of which was subpar. 

Do NOT work at this place.  Actually most fully online adjunct faculty positions are like this.  You would be better off being a tutor.

review_title: Finance counselor; good company; good pay.

cons: student load can be difficult, dealing with the politics and students.

review_title: The Keystone Cops of Online Education
pros: A relatively sound introduction to their online platform. Not much in the way of many online trainings at other institutions, where very inexperienced "trainers" barely participate in discussions about the very basics of educational theory, having little or no experience in the classroom. The training is lacking in a few areas, but is primarily very thorough run-through of the GCU system. As far as the system goes, there are very few surprises to encounter (with the platform) once you are teaching your first class.
cons: Often laughably poor curriculum that cannot be altered by faculty in any way. The canned curriculum is questionable at Gen. Ed. (Freshmen) level, but is uniformly behind the times (by twenty or thirty years) in Sophomore to Senior level courses. I taught two separate semesters (my last two) where textbooks were not delivered to me for several weeks. No-one (not the GCU bookstore, not faculty "support," not the executives who then oversaw bookstore operations) responded to the very serious issue that I couldn't teach the course without the textbook. Generally, emails and voicemails tend to be ignored. Who was my supervisor? Academic Affairs? The Dean? Faculty Support? The Bookstore? This organization are so disorganized, I never knew who I reported to. If you need to contact HR about any issue whatsoever, don't expect a response. Many of the faculty support staff members were functionally illiterate (something I am qualified to assess), though they seemed to be trained to send one or two of around ten canned messages back to faculty members who had questions, no matter that these "answers" didn't really address the faculty members' questions.

pros: Automatic raise to 50k after 2 yrs, free College for you + Spouse & Dependents. Work from home opportunities. Cheap health insurance although they will pass on costs associated with ACA onto their employees.
cons: No upward mobility (even if you are a top performer), there is no growth model as an EC (all counselors are paid the same regardless of their performance), vision & direction change weekly, employees are treated as disposable assets even the employees retaining & recruiting the most students, the job can be very boring after a while, cold calling tactics & you are encouraged to push prospects so they will enroll, can be very difficult at times to effectively interface with other department employees, management lies to employees about raises & they will not take care of good employees. There is zero incentive to perform. Mundane employees keep their jobs & good employees will be asked to do more for no more pay. Overtime is slowly being phased out, pay is extremely low while other Universities are paying $20k more a year starting out for the same position, you can expect between 1-3% Max raise per year, your enrollments will never be enough & there is always something your doing wrong, heavy culture of right wing politics & many here masquerade under the banner of God, the University does not support the rights of same sex couples either.

pros: The team in the College of Education is second to none. The environment is friendly and very team-oriented. There is definitely a culture of continuous improvement and everyone on our team worked well together for common goals.

pros: Regarding GCU Online, I can only list potential education benefits as a pro.  It is a terrible environment for staff.
cons:
The reviews I have read are accurate in regard to GCU Online.  GCU is a private, for-profit university attempting to appeal to students as a "Christian" university.  I saw nothing in online management I would define as "Christian" in the treatment of employees. Working at the ground campus may be different.

It was to GCU's detriment that Mr. Mueller was wooed away from UOP/Apollo Group.  Not only did he bring his cronies with him, he has and is creating another UOP where he is the supreme ruler and is surrounded by the minions of his choosing. 

Working in the Doctoral College, Enrollment Counselors were required to be articulate and educated.  However, leadership spent the majority of time in the office patrolling the area to ensure no one had a mobile phone out or was eating anything more than a snack at his or her desk.  Enrollment is a call center with a call center mentality.  Unreasonable expectations of sales and solicitation calls and dismissal of employees for legitimate medical reasons.  I saw this occur on multiple occasions.  At no point were employees offered FMLA if ill, they were terminated.

In addition, there are absolutely NO admission requirements for entry into a doctoral program. The ONLY admission requirement is the ability to pay, typically using Title IV funding (Student Loans).  Prospective doctoral students planning to invest a substantial amount of money into an education NEED to consider the value of the degree conferred. 

GCU is an institution not about education; it is about making as much money as possible.  I urge anyone looking for a good university to look at other institutions.  If a private Christian university will treat its employees poorly, I find it hard to believe students are a priority.
